abstract: Standard Chartered to will pay a $300 million fine for backsliding. | A default swaps association has postponed a payout auction on Argentine bonds. | Grappling with the cost of corporate gadflies. | Bank of America has a sole chief operating officer.
snippet: Standard Chartered to will pay a $300 million fine for backsliding. | A default swaps association has postponed a payout auction on Argentine bonds. | Grappling with the cost of corporate gadflies. | Bank of America has a sole chief operating offi...
lead_paragraph: In a settlement announced on Tuesday by New York State’s financial regulator, the British bank Standard Chartered will pay a $300 million fine and suspend its dollar-clearing activities because of its failure to weed out transactions prone to money-laundering, Ben Protess and Chad Bray write in DealBook. The deal comes two years after the bank paid a combined $667 million to state and federal authorities over similar accusations. Those settlements resolved accusations that Standard Chartered, in part through its New York branch, processed transactions for Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Standard Chartered’s Backsliding Woes
